name: Linux
description: Most of the time our applications are deployed on Linux based platforms. Basic knowledge of this platform will help you install your stuff in the right place and easily and quickly diagnose problems.

topics.name: Basic Linux
topics.description: One of the most common tasks for a dev on a Linux machine is inspection, e.g.: "what on this machine causes my software to not run the way it should", or: "What do the logs say?". To do so you need to know how to get access to a terminal, how to navigate and where to look.

resources.name: Find Files in Linux, Using the Command Line
View and Follow the End of Text Files with tail
Use Killall and Kill Commands to Stop Processes on Linux
How to Use Nano Text Editor Commands in Linux
How to Grep for Text in Files
Stackoverflow: How to use/send signals at the command-line for any program

abilities: Navigating the directory structure of a Linux box from the terminal.
Search for a specific file by name within the file system.
Search through file(s) by content.
Know the common places to look for log files.
Know the common places to look for configuration files.
Run a command as super user using "sudo".
Find a process id.
Send a signal (e.g.: KILL, HUP) to a process.

topics.name: Linux Filesystem
topics.description: Everything related to a Linux system can be found in the filesystem. Actual files, devices, statistics, everything. It is important to know what can be found where (and why!)
abilities: List the various types of (pseudo)files that can exist in the Linux system.
Explain the purpose of the directories present at the root level of most linux filesystem.

topics.name: Networking I
topics.description: Common tools for inspecting and manipulating the network configuration of a Linux machine. E.g.: iproute2, netstat, inspecting the system route table and running traceroutes.
abilities: Inspect the networking configuration of a Linux machine.
Perform basic troubleshooting of network issues, e.g.: is there a process listening on this port, do my routes check out.

resources.name: How to user traceroute and mtr to diagnose network issues

topics.name: Managing Processes
topics.description: On a linux machine processes run in a tree, always having an "init" process at the root that is owned by the root user, all processes are (in)direct children of this process. There exist various tools to inspect and manage this tree of processes such as "ps", "top", and "kill". Finally the permissions of a process are determined by the user who owns the process,
abilities: Explain the relationship between processes, users and groups.
Explain the purpose of the root process.
Diagnose issues with running processes, using tools like "*top".

resources.name: How to use ps, kill and nice to manage processes in Linux

topics.name: Mandatory Access Control
topics.description: Within Linux several frameworks exist to further limit the access of processes to files, frameworks such as SELinux and AppArmor.
abilities: Have knowledge of methods for further limiting access to files & directories (beyond users/groups/ACLs)
List the two most common frameworks used for enabling such access control.

resources.name: An Introduction to SELinux on CentOS 7 â€“ Part 1: Basic Concepts

topics.name: Remote Access
topics.description: Linux servers are most commonly accessed by SSH. There are some good things to know about SSH such as known hosts, verification and how public/private keys work. In addition to that SSH can also be used as a simple (vpn like) tunnel.
abilities: Log into a Linux box using SSH.
Generating ssh private keys.
Setting up a port forward on an SSH tunnel.
Execute commands directly on remote host.
Understand the limitations of SSH (e.g.: what happens if I start a long running migration in an SSH session and my connection breaks)

topics.name: Using Bash
topics.description: The most common shell on Linux is bash. Bash and its associated utilities probably deserve a knowledge graph on their own. However even with some basic knowledge about subjects such as piping and output redirection, and where to find the manual, it can quickly become a powerful tool for any user.
abilities: Redirect output of a program to a file and/or another program.
Redirect stdout to stderr and vice versa.
Write a basic bash script.
Basic data manipulation, e.g.: search/replace, remove a column from a csv, extract values from json.

topics.name: Networking II
topics.description:
Linux has a very powerful network stack that can go well beyond the traditional "hook up a single computer to the network" case.

Examples include multiple internal networks to seperate containers / VMs, acting as a router in a network.. This complexity also means that sometimes detecting performance issues is notrivial. There is an extensive toolset for managing and inspecting this all, like IPTables (+applications wrapping it), network performance measurement tools (iperf), packet sniffers (tcpdump, wireshark), nmap (detecting open ports).
abilities: Set up a Linux machine as a router/gateway for a network.
Dump raw network traffic on an interface
Open and close ports using IPTables.
Set up a local network on a single host, that is granted NATted access to the internet.

topics.name: Package management
topics.description: There are almost as many different package managers as there are Linux distributions. However they share many common operations, just with a different syntax. The goal of this topic is to get an understanding of the common operations: installing, removing, upgrading.
abilities: Know how to use at least one of the following package managers: apt, yum, dnf
Explain the risks associated with adding third party repositories.
Be able to install your own (manually packaged) software on a Linux machine in the proper location.

resources.name: Unix Stackexchange - What is the difference between /opt  and /usr/local
AskUbuntu - Why should I move everything into opt

topics.name: Inspecting Disks
topics.description: A common cause of outages on Linux machines is disk issues, a harddrive getting filled up or broken. Knowing how to inspect the status of disks is key to diagnosing issues.
abilities: Determine if a specific disk/partition is getting full.
Check a filesystem for errors.

resources.name: Troubleshooting disk space issues on Linux

topics.name: Managing Disks I
topics.description: Managing the drives of a linux system, partitioning, mounting and filesystem choice.
abilities: Partitioning and formatting disks
Choosing an appropriate filesystem for your use-case
Working with fstab

topics.name: Managing Disks II
topics.description: Managing the drives of a linux system, creating advanced layouts using LVM, device mapper and md..
abilities: Set up raid arrays on Linux machines.
Create and administer encrypted volumes.
Be able to use LVM to create several volumes on a single encrypted volume.
Combining and stacking the various technologies for aggregating disks.
Creating cheap system snapshots.

topics.name: Network Drives
topics.description: Managing the drives of a linux system: mounting network drives/shares. Both on the block level (iscsi) and filesystem level it is possible to mount network drives.
abilities: Mount network based drives / file systems, your machine being the client.
Export network based drives, your machine being the host/server

resources.name: Arch Wiki - File systems # Clustered file systems

topics.name: Users and Groups
topics.description: Linux has users, and groups to group those users. There exist various tools for creating, listing and managing these entities. In addition to that there are several special users/groups, such as "root" and several methods of privilege escalation.
abilities: Adding and removing (system) accounts.
Adding and removing groups.
Adding and removing users to groups.
Granting and revoking sudo permissions for specific commands.

topics.name: File Access Permissions I
topics.description: Access to files in Linux is primarily determined by the user and group who own the files and the permissions set on the file.
abilities: Working with user/group based permissions.
Changing a file's modebits

resources.name: Arch Wiki - File permissions and attributes

topics.name: File Access Permissions II
topics.description: In some cases the user/group mechanism is not granular enough for granting the right permissions. For this it is possible to add extended access control lists to files.
abilities: Extending the permissions on files/directories using Access Control Lists
Inspecting the ACLs of a file.

topics.name: Managing Services & Tasks I
topics.description:
Common tools for managing services on Linux, primarily systemd.

 SystemD is what is used by most major distrubutions (e.g.: redhat/fedora/centos, debian/ubuntu, opensuse)
abilities: Manage existing services using systemd.
Set up scheduled tasks using cron.

resources.name: Arch Wiki - Systemd, section: Basic Systemctl Usage

topics.name: Managing Services & Tasks II
topics.description:
Common tools for managing services on Linux, primarily systemd.

 SystemD is what is used by most major distrubutions (e.g.: redhat/fedora/centos, debian/ubuntu, opensuse)
abilities: Create your own system services to be managed by SystemD
Override specific parts of existing service configurations using Drop-in files
Setting up timers

topics.name: Performance Debugging
topics.description:
Occasionally you will encounter performance issues with applications. These may stem from the linux kernel.

Debugging such problems can be both challenging and fun given the right tools. And horribly frustrating without them.
abilities: Debug performance issues on a linux machine.
